@ProfessorDaveExplains  OK, but now I can't see why it isn't symmetrical. That is, I can't see why the interval isn't 0 <= x <= 2. Regardless of whether x is 0 or 2, you have +/-1 in the numerator all the way to infinity, while the denominator goes to infinity, so surely it would converge?  By the way, I've found your series very helpful. I tried university maths about 25 years ago, but they lost me with too much info too quick, filling countless blackboards with theorem proofs, and I like that you just show us what we need to solve the basic problems that we're likely to get on an exam.

It comes from the ratio test, which states that if |a_(n+1)/a_n|<1, the series absolutely converges. If it were >1, it would diverge, and if =1, the test would be inconclusive

You need to check the endpoints. Simply plug in the values of the endpoint into the original power series and see if it converges. If it does converge then the endpoint is included, if it does not then it is not included.
